abstract.text: A control that displays one or more buttons in a tab bar for selecting between different subtasks, views, or modes in an app.

legalNotices.copyright: Copyright © 2025 Apple Inc. All rights reserved.

inlineContent.text: Typically, you use tab bars in conjunction with a
object, but you can also use them as standalone controls in your app. Tab bars always appear across the bottom edge of the screen and display the contents of one or more

objects. A tab bar’s appearance can be customized with a background image or tint color to suit the needs of your interface. Tapping an item selects and highlights that item, and you use the selection of the item to enable the corresponding mode for your app.
You can configure tab bars programmatically or in Interface Builder. A
object provides its own tab bar object and you must configure the object provided to you. When creating a tab bar programmatically, use the

method or another view initializer method to set its initial configuration. Use the methods of this class to configure the appearance of the tab bar. For tab bars you create yourself, you also use the methods of this class to specify the items displayed by the tab bar.
The
class and

classes have similar appearances but different purposes. Use tab bars to convey and change your app’s mode. Use toolbars to present the user with a set of actions that are relevant to the currently presented content.

A tab bar reports selections and user customizations to its delegate object. For tab bars you create yourself, use the delegate to respond to selections or to the addition, removal, or reordering of items in the tab bar. (A
object acts as the delegate for the tab bar it manages.) For more information on implementing a tab bar delegate, see

You can configure tab bar items using Interface Builder or create and configure them programmatically in your code. Tab bars in Interface Builder come preconfigured with some initial items and you can add, remove, or reorder items as needed. How you configure items at design time depends on whether your tab bar is associated with a
object:
Configuring your tab bar in Interface Builder:
When a

object is present, add or remove view controllers to your scene and create relationship segues between the tab bar controller and each new view controller. Creating a relationship segue automatically adds a new item to the tab bar, and deleting an existing relationship segue removes the corresponding tab bar item.
When a tab bar controller isn’t present, drag tab bar items from the library onto your tab bar.
Configuring your tab bar programmatically:
To configure the tab bar associated with a
object, configure the view controllers associated with the tab bar controller. The tab bar automatically obtains its items from the
property of each view controller associated with the tab bar controller.
To configure tab bar items directly, use the
method of the tab bar itself.
A tab bar displays all of its tabs onscreen at once, using the

property to determine how to position items in the available space. If you have more items than can fit in the available space, display only a subset of them and let the user select which tabs are displayed. The
method displays an interface for selecting which tab bar items to display.
The contents of each item are stored in a

object. Each item contains a title and an image to display in the tab. You can also use tab bar items to add a badge to the corresponding tab. For more information about creating and configuring items, see

For tab bars with an associated tab bar controller, the tab bar controller automatically manages selections and displays the appropriate view controller. The only time you have to manage selections yourself is when you create the tab bar without a tab bar controller. The tab bar reports selections to the
method of its
object, which you can use to respond to selection changes. For more information about implementing the delegate object, see

content.text: Configure a tab bar with Interface Builder

inlineContent.text: The following table lists the attributes that you configure for tab bars in Interface Builder.
Attribute
Discussion
Background

The background image to display for the bar. If you specify a stretchable image, the image is stretched to fit the available space; otherwise, the image is tiled. When you configure a background image, the tab bar ignores the tint color information. To set this attribute programmatically, use the
property.
Shadow
The custom shadow image for the tab bar. This attribute is ignored if the tab bar does not also have a custom background image. To set this attribute programmatically, use the
property.
Selection
The image to use for the selected tab. To set this attribute programmatically, use the
property.
Image Tint
The tint color to apply to the selected item. To set this attribute programmatically, use the
property.
Style
The basic style to apply to the bar. You can configure a tab bar with a dark or light style and the bar can be opaque or translucent. To set the style programmatically, use the
and
properties.
Bar Tint
The tint color to apply to the bar. To set this attribute programmatically, use the
property.
Item Positioning
The positioning scheme to apply to items. Use this attribute to configure how items are spaced across the length of the tab bar. To set this attribute programmatically, use the
property.
To internationalize a tab bar, you must provide localized strings for the tab bar item titles.
For more information, see
Tab bars are accessible by default.

With VoiceOver enabled on an iOS device, when a user touches a tab in a tab bar, VoiceOver reads the title of the tab, its position in the bar, and whether it’s selected. For example in the iTunes app on iPad, you might hear “Selected, Audiobooks, four of seven” or “Genius, six of seven.”
For general information about making your interface accessible, see
For design guidance, see

abstract.text: Construct and manage a graphical, event-driven user interface for your iOS, iPadOS, or tvOS app.
Methods that associate a unique identifier with elements in your user interface.
An interface that provides a source for shareable content to fulfill user requests to share current content.
A collection of methods that gives you access to the appearance proxy for a class.
A protocol that a class must adopt to allow appearance customization using the
API.
A set of methods for converting between different frames of reference on a screen.
A set of methods that can make a custom object eligible to participate in UIKit Dynamics.
A set of methods that define the focus behavior for a branch of the view hierarchy.
An object that can become focused.
The container responsible for providing geometric context to focus items within a given focus environment.
Methods that provide details about how to display your custom content in the large content viewer.
Navigational controls that display in a bar along the top of the screen, usually in conjunction with a navigation controller.
A container view controller that defines a stack-based scheme for navigating hierarchical content.
The items that a navigation bar displays when the associated view controller is visible.
A container view controller that manages navigation between pages of content, where a subview controller manages each page.
The interface that determines whether a responder object supports paste configuration.
A type that can be an anchor for a popover presentation controller.
A set of standard methods that apps can adopt to support editing.
A tab subclass that represents the system’s search tab.
A container view controller that implements a hierarchical interface.
The interface that determines if an object supports a spring-loaded interaction for drag and drop activities.
An object that manages a tab in a tab bar.
A control that displays one or more buttons in a tab bar for selecting between different subtasks, views, or modes in an app.
The custom background image for the tab bar.
The tab bar style that specifies its appearance.
The tint color to apply to the tab bar background.
Presents a standard interface that lets the user customize the contents of the tab bar.
The tab bar’s delegate object.
Dismisses the standard interface used to customize the tab bar.
A Boolean value indicating whether the user is currently customizing the tab bar.
A Boolean value that indicates whether the tab bar is translucent.
The positioning scheme for the tab bar items in the tab bar.
The items displayed by the tab bar.
The view at the leading edge of a tab bar on tvOS.
The appearance settings for the tab bar when the edge of scrollable content aligns with the edge of the tab bar.
The currently selected item on the tab bar.
The image to use for the selection indicator.
Sets the items on the tab bar, optionally animating any changes into position.
The shadow image to use for the tab bar.
The appearance settings for a standard-height tab bar.
The tint color to apply to the tab bar items.
The view at the trailing edge of a tab bar on tvOS.
A container view controller that manages a multiselection interface, where the selection determines which child view controller to display.
The
protocol defines optional methods for a delegate of a
object. The

class provides the ability for the user to reorder, remove, and add items to the tab bar; this process is referred to as customizing the tab bar. The tab bar delegate receives messages when customizing occurs.
Sent to the delegate when the user selects a tab bar item.
An object that describes an item in a tab bar.
An object that manages a collection of tab objects.
A control that displays one or more buttons along the bottom edge of your interface.
A type that calls your code in reaction to changes in the trait environment.
A set of methods that makes the iOS interface environment available to your app.
The protocol you adopt to restore an object’s state from a user activity.
An object that manages the content for a rectangular area on the screen.
Creates a view with the specified frame rectangle.
The tab bar item that represents the view controller when added to a tab bar controller.
Make your UIKit apps accessible to everyone who uses iOS and tvOS.
Create a composite interface by combining content from one or more view controllers with other custom views.

abstract.text: Customize appearance information directly on the tab bar object.
Methods your app can implement to respond to layer-related events.
A protocol that enables an object to be encoded and decoded for archiving and distribution.
The group of methods that are fundamental to all Objective-C objects.
A protocol that an object adopts to create a bar object in your app.
A type that can be hashed into a `Hasher` to produce an integer hash value.
A type that can be compared for value equality.
A singleton actor whose executor is equivalent to the main dispatch queue.
A type with a customized textual representation.
A type with a customized textual representation suitable for debugging purposes.
A type whose instances can be encoded, and appropriately passed, as elements of a C `va_list`.
A type whose values can be implicitly or explicitly copied.
A thread-safe type whose values can be shared across arbitrary concurrent contexts without introducing a risk of data races.
